Scenario 1. False positive in the serological assay.
Scenario 2. A non-COVID infection in December, followed by an asymptomatic COVID-19 infection between Feb and April.
Scenario 3. A bona fide COVID-19 infection in December.

label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: We are making significant strides at unprecedented speed in developing diagnostics, therapeutics & vaccines for #COVID19. Yet far more work is needed to end this global health crisis. With your support, #NIH is on the case!

label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: A Phase 2 #clinicaltrial of this #COVID19 vaccine candidate began on May 29th. This month, #NIH plans to launch a Phase 3 clinical trial that will seek to enroll 30,000 volunteers, with results expected in a few months.

label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: Still, the ultimate tool we need to end the #COVID19 pandemic is a vaccine. Operation Warp Speed & #ACTIV are working together intensively on vaccine development. A scientific review of more than 50 vaccine candidates has already been conducted. #NIH

label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: But it‚Äôs not enough to diagnose this disease. We must treat it, and, as soon as possible, prevent it. To that end, #NIH has launched the Accelerating COVID-19 Therapeutic Interventions and Vaccines, or #ACTIV, Initiative:  https://www.nih.gov/research-training/medical-research-initiatives/activ¬†‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/RZJZSorqWE

label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: Scaling to rapid, routine point-of-care testing would be a major advantage but requires new tech. label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: Testing in the US has also come a long way: 30M+ tests for presence of the #COVID19 have been administered in the last few months, more than in any other nation. Yet these tests are not entirely satisfactory for the needs at hand. #NIH

label: real
statement: .@NIHDirector on the Hill: Based on hard work, we now have better means of treating #COVID19 than just a few months ago. Remdesivir and dexamethasone have proven beneficial in rigorous trials and are now standard of care for hospitalized patients. #NIH

statement: For Arizona, we have 4140 deaths reported as of Aug 8 and 144k cases reported as of July 19. This implies between 576k infections and 1.15M infections on July 19. This equates to a lag-adjusted IFR of between 0.4% and 0.7%. 13/16

label: real
statement: For Texas, we have 8866 deaths reported as of Aug 8 and 325k cases reported as of July 19. This implies between 1.3M infections and 2.6M infections on July 19. This equates to a lag-adjusted IFR of between 0.3% and 0.7%. 12/16

label: real
statement: For Florida, we have 8108 deaths reported as of Aug 8 and 350k cases reported as of July 19. This implies between 1.4M infections and 2.8M infections on July 19. This equates to a lag-adjusted IFR of between 0.3% and 0.6%. 11/16

label: real
statement: Here, I assume a range of underreporting of catching between 1 infection in 4 as a case to 1 infection in 8. With 1 in 4, total infections are 4X total cases. With 1 in 8, total infections are 8X total cases. 10/16

statement: We can ballpark a lag-adjusted IFR by comparing total deaths reported today to estimated infections 20 days ago, ie July 19. 9/16

statement: Thus, we often have a ~48hr window after an index case develops symptoms to test and alert contacts. This turnaround is highly challenging, but if done in time and Bob is alerted to quarantine we can break the transmission cycle. 8/14 pic.twitter.com/f0QnBcuTbc

statement: In order for #TestTraceIsolate to be truly effective, Bob needs to be alerted by day 7 to quarantine. This is a tight timeline. It requires that Alice get tested on day 5 when she develops symptoms and rapid turnover of lab assay and alerting. 7/14

statement: Again, there are a bunch of assumptions here, and the main point is not the ~20k number, but instead that what we're seeing now are not new introductions, but small outbreaks that have been growing locally over the past ~8 weeks and now getting big enough to be noticed. 12/13

label: real
statement: I could easily be off 2-fold in either direction, but my best guess is that we're currently in the 10,000 to 40,000 range nationally. 11/13

label: real
statement: This fits with estimates of a rough 1 to 10 case to infection reporting rate and a currently reported 1875 cases.  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html¬†‚Ä¶ 10/13

label: real
statement: Thus, a rough guess would be a ~20 sparks that caught between Jan 15 and Feb 15 and have resulted in growing outbreaks, each of which on average will be around ~1000 infections, some bigger than others. This would be an extremely rough ~20k infections in the USA. 9/13

label: real
statement: Many of these ~45 cases that arrived will have fizzled without causing downstream transmission, but still a number of these likely caught hold. 8/13

label: real
statement: Given that the US detected 15 cases from Jan 15 to Feb 15, we might very roughly expect 45 other mild cases that arrived and were not picked up by surveillance. 7/13

label: real
statement: Colleagues at @MRC_Outbreak estimate that sensitivity to detect a travel export from Wuhan was only about 1 in 4 internationally, mainly due to spectrum of disease severity (report 6  https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-infectious-disease-analysis/news--wuhan-coronavirus/¬†‚Ä¶). 6/13

label: real
statement: The seeming sudden appearance of outbreaks across the US are not due to a sudden influx of cases. Instead, transmission chains have been percolating for 4-8 weeks now and we're just now starting to see exponential growth pick up steam. 5/13

label: real
statement: I believe that a 5-6 day doubling is an accurate model for growth, so that sparks that landed in mid-Jan may have grown to ~2000 infections at this point and sparks that arrived in mid-Feb may have grown to ~50 infections at this point. 4/13

label: real
statement: Although it looks like I was off by a week or two, I think the basic model was sound. Outbreaks that we're seeing across the US now are likely the result of sparks that landed in mid-Jan to mid-Feb that through exponential growth have become localized "fires". 3/13

label: real
statement: I posted back in Feb 8 with this simple model ( https://twitter.com/trvrb/status/1226241415522373632¬†‚Ä¶), in which the Wuhan outbreak took from Nov to mid-Jan to grow big enough to throw off sparks and that we should expect another ~10 weeks for these sparks to grow into fires. 2/13

statement: I don't doubt community spread is happening Ohio and it's highly difficult to do these prevalence estimates well without wider surveillance efforts, but I think this is certainly a strong overestimate. 5/5

statement: Another way to look at this is that it took the virus from ~Nov 1 to Feb 1 to reach 100k infections in Wuhan. This is ~90 days. Thus, it would have had to have been circulating in Ohio since mid-Dec for this to be the case, which is almost certainly not the case. 4/5
